Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Understanding the Development of Sustainable Information Infrastructures for Digital Preservation to Support Marginalized Communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
The long-term preservation of digital information requires sustainable infrastructure. Social and technical elements, including people, organizations, hardware, software, and communication technologies, combine to form infrastructures that support preservation and access to digital information such as research data and personal records. This research seeks to understand the lifecycles and outcomes of digital preservation projects, focusing on projects whose goals included supporting communities experiencing identity, memory, and accountability crises such as children in care. In order to inform future infrastructure development, the goals of this study are to identify those factors that contribute to successful sustainable infrastructure development, to understand the types of challenges that arise in the development process and how those challenges are overcome. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Joanne Evans at Monash University in Melbourne, Australia. Australia has a strong public records infrastructure, making this site an ideal location for this project. Findings from this research could inform the development and study of recordkeeping infrastructures in the United States.

This research employs a mixed methods approach, pairing a large-scale survey with in-depth semi-structured interviews and observations. Using a theoretical framework based on theories of infrastructure development this study seeks to understand the outcomes of digital information and research data management projects funded by the Australian National Data Service (ANDS). This study of ANDS-funded projects will be one of the first to look at an entire ecosystem of federally-funded projects, generating baseline data that will provide insight into what factors contribute to successful digital preservation infrastructure development.

This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Australian Academy of Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Access to digital information is a critical underpinning of core values in our society, from open government, to research and scholarship. Digital preservation is about ensuring the viability, sustainability, and accessibility of digital information over time, and long-term preservation requires sustainable infrastructure. In collaboration with Dr. Joanne Evans at Monash University (Melbourne, VIC, Australia) this project examined the lifecycle and outcomes of digital preservation projects supported by the Australian National Data Service (ANDS).  Specifically, those projects whose goals included supporting communities experiencing identity, memory, and accountability crises such as children in care. This ongoing project aims to identify factors that contribute to sustainable infrastructure development, to understand the types of challenges that arise in the development process, and how those challenges are overcome.

To examine the development of sustainable infrastructure for digital preservation, this research paired a survey with interviews. Study participants included ANDS staff members, and project managers and team members from ANDS-supported projects. The goals of both the survey and interviews were to understand the lifecycle of the projects and whether they were able to successfully create sustainable infrastructures that have remained in place beyond the period of initial funding.  Additionally, interview questions were designed to investigate what factors may have contributed to the success or failure of these projects, to identify difficulties encountered, and how project personnel responded to these challenges.

Preliminary findings suggest that ANDS itself played a significant role in the long-term success of infrastructure development projects. In addition to providing financial support for these projects, ANDS staff also provided consulting and expertise to project teams, and acted as connectors and facilitators to additional resources and information. Affiliation with a larger project emerged as another factor that contributed to the success of infrastructure development projects. Teams that developed infrastructure in order to preserve and/or provide access to data for a larger project, that had multiple sources of funding, were more likely to report long-term success. Teams that were contributing to a larger infrastructure development project were also likely to report success.  Finally, additional support from organizations such as a university library or e-research center also appeared to be a factor that contributed to the success of these projects. A significant challenge that emerged is the difficulty that project teams encountered when the needs of the individuals or communities represented in the data conflicted with the goals or capabilities of the digital preservation infrastructure. For example, records that contained sensitive information about living individuals may require restrictions to access that are difficult to enact selectively across a larger body of data.

Together, these preliminary findings indicate that the development of sustainable infrastructure for digital preservation requires a robust network of individuals and organizations, collaborating across all phases of the project to ensure the production of sustainable infrastructure that will meet the needs of a variety of stakeholder groups and persist beyond the initial phases of development.
